definition: the whole nest came out (idiom); to turn out in full strength
to overturn/to collapse/to lean/to tend/to incline/to pour out
and/as well as/and so/but (not)/yet (not)/(indicates causal relation)/(indicates change of state)/(indicates contrast)

to go out/to come out/to occur/to produce/to go beyond/to rise/to put forth/to happen/(used after a verb to indicate an outward direction or a positive result)/classifier for dramas, plays, operas etc
variant of 出[chu1] (classifier for plays or chapters of classical novels)

sentences.english: A rumbling sound started, and the rats poured out from all of the houses.
sentences.chinese: 传来一阵隆隆声，老鼠从房子里倾巢而出。

sentences.english: The whole city turned out to cheer the Pope .
sentences.chinese: 全城居民倾巢而出欢迎教皇。

sentences.english: Bigwigs on both sides were also in full-gush mode.

definition: lit. the whole nest came out (to fight us)/a turnout in full force (of a gang of villains)
total defeat of an army (idiom); fig. a complete wipeout
raid/to carry out a raid/to invade
to start out on a trip/to dispatch troops
to fish by casting a net/to capture/to surround and seize
to besiege/to beleaguer/to attack from all sides/to jointly speak or write against sb
